ns:description.ns:full:
Cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other) of Bronze Age date.

The OS record cairns at this site (S1361), but Clare could not locate 1972 during survey for an MA thesis - site no. 401 (S1939). A group of five cairns on a large area of gentle to moderate sloped, non-undulating, well-drained moorland with only occasional outcrop and surface stone. The cairns are for the most part well-defined and slightly prominent, one of them is superimposed on a large natural in situ block and it would appear that these are the product of stone clearance activity. Their distribution is in a broad band orientated downslope adjacent to a large crag and may reflect clearance along the edge of agriculturally viable ground. This site was identified during a LUAU survey of Torver High Common in 1994 (S1893).

Monument Type: Monument

ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:description.ns:full:
Cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other) within which are two hut circle settlements (round houses indicated by the presence of a low, roughly circular bank of turf, earth or stone, which formed the base of the walls) each with an associated field system (a group or complex of fields which appear to form a coherent whole) and 15 funerary cairns (stony mounds containing or concealing deliberately deposited human remains) all of Bronze Age date. Two urn finds of Bronze Age date from these cairns are in the Cambridge Museum of Archaeology and Ethnology. There is also a farmstead (a farmhouse and ancillary farm buildings forming a group) with an associated field system and trackway of Romano-British date and a shieling (pasture to which animals were driven for grazing, with associated temporary huts for domestic or agricultural use) of Medieval date. Scheduled Ancient Monument no. 32861. See associated HERs 31017, 31018, 31019 and 31020.

A complex of walls and some 300-400 cairns. Some cairns dug 19th century had "cinerary urns?a few fragments of pottery and some burnt bone." 2 of the urns are at Cambridge Museum of Archaeology and Ethnology (S1361). Additional excavations 1957,1958 by Walker, but no artefacts found. Pollen analysis suggested area was forested and the vegetation disturbed by the construction of the cairns. Walker suggests the cairns may be connected with the deforestation of the area (S2213 p. 53-65). See 'The History of the County of Cumberland' by Hutchinson in 1794 (S1227 p. 562, 575), 'The History and Antiquities of Cumberland II' by Jefferson in 1842 (S1221 p. 211-212) and 'A Guide to Prehistoric England' by Thomas (S1433 p. 60). See 'Buildings of England: Cumberland & Westmorland' by Pevsner in 1967 (S1370 p. 1660). See article 'Prehistorians and Pastoralists in neolithic and Bronze Age England' by Richard Bradley in the 1972 (4) volume of the journal World Archaeology (S2266 p. 192-204). See T. Clare's MA thesis site no. 387 (S1939). Cairns, tracks and banks are also present to the south according to George & Crawford (S1116 p. 46). Listed by Challis and Harding as an extensive Bronze Age settlement with enclosures and hut circles (S1055 p. 2). Note: the 1980 volume of C&WAAS was checked but the article appeared to not relate to this site. See article 'Excavations at Birrel Sike' in the 1982 volume of C&WAAS (S1870 p. 7-25). See article 'Settlements and groups of small cairns on Birkby and Birker Fell' by Leech in the 1983 volume of C&WAAS (S1896 p. 15-22). A survey conducted by CLAU in 1988 identified a large area of cairns and associated field system and settlement on a gently sloping, raised plateau, which is edged in all directons by areas of bog. It would appear that there was more than one phase of settlement on Barnscar. The road and associated banks clearly relate to the farmstead; yet the field plots and some of the cairns in the southern part of the site, relate to a rectilinear platform, which was a very different form of domestic structure and was not necessarily contemporary with the farmstead. The present form of the cairnfield was probably the product of many phases of use and the cairnfield may have been significantly altered after its initial construction. Detailed information on each feature is available in the CLAU Site Catalogue (S1920). Detailed information on the excavated cairns within this group are under HER 31017, the settlement is HER 31019, an enclosure at SD1349395747 is HER 31020 and a hut and enclosure at SD1338296104 are HER 31018. The site is visible on aerial photographs from the CLAU (S923) and Cumbria County Council (S917) collections. Also see the Cumbria County Council slide collection (S1047). See scheduling details for full description (S904, S905) For more information regarding archaeological investigation and excavation at this site see the NMR Excavation Index 645850, 629371, 629373 (S1347). Two urns are at the Cambridge Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology, Accession nos. 1925.472 and 1925.473 (L.Keys 09/2006).

Monument Type: Monument

Monument Status: Scheduled Monument

ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:appellation.ns:name: Beacon Tarn Cairnfield, Blawith and Subberthwaite

ns:description.ns:full:
Cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other) of Bronze Age date.

Mounds and cairns located on a rocky shoulder (centre SD272896), vary from 8 ft to 15 ft in diameter (S1361). Fell considered them possible burial mounds, owing to their "skyline position," but T Clare said it was difficult to see the cairns at all from below and that the majority did not appear on the skyline - site no. 456 (S1939). See article 'Cairns in High Furness' by C.I. Fell in the 1964 volume of C&WAAS (S2211 p. 1-3). See also HER 2155. A large group of cairns spread out across a wide area of landscape strewn with natural ridges and small terraces. The cairns are not specifically grouped although some do seem to coincide with areas of possibly improved ground. All the cairns seem to be between 3m to 4m in maximum length and most are irregular and ill-defined. This seems to indicate opportunistic clearance. This site was located during a field survey conducted by LUAU in 1995 (S1894).

Monument Type: Monument

ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:appellation.ns:name: Bootle Fell, Cairns 910 m E of Low Kinmont, Bootle

ns:description.ns:full:
Cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other) and a stone bank (linear or curvilinear construction of stone) of Bronze Age date. Included within Scheduled Ancient Monument no. 32833.

Numerous mounds and heaps of stone are located on the W slope of a hill. There are also remains of walls. There are other cairnfields nearby. See HER 1489- 1491. Central grid ref given for groups of cairns (S1361). See AM County Index for details. This SMR no covers AM County nos 50a-s AM Site nos 021438-021456 (S904). See the Inventory of ancient monuments in Cumberland in the 1923 volume of C&WAAS (S1905 p. 268). See 'The Gosforth District: Its Antiquities and Places of Interest' by C. Parker in 1926 (S1364 p. 231). See also site envelope. See the C&WAAS regional group report by Hyam in 1958 (S2003 p. 20). See T. Clare's MA thesis site no. 44 (S1939). The site is included in Crawford & George's archaeological survey of Copeland (S1116 p. 56). The CLAU Survey identified a large number of cairns, many of which are small and ill-defined, and a number of distinctive monuments. These include a large, prominent cairn, of regular shape, which is SMR No. 31035. There are also 9 examples of approx. semi-circular stone bank, all of a similar size. The opening faces west or north-west, towards the prevailing winds and the interior is irregular and bumpy, with no indication of internal levelling or terracing. Because the open side is exposed to wind it is unlikely these are shelters or bields and with a lack of internal levelling they are unlikely to be hut platforms. Their function is unknown and it cannot be ascertained whether they are contemporary with the main group of cairns. Another funerary cairn is SMR No. 31036 (S1917). The site is now included within an extensive area of scheduling. See scheduling details (S905). The site is visible on aerial photographs from the Cumbria County Council collection (S917).

Monument Type: Monument

Monument Status: Scheduled Monument

ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:appellation.ns:name: Brantrake Moss, Birkby Fell Cairnfield, Eskdale

ns:description.ns:full:
Cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other) of Bronze Age date. Included within Scheduled Ancient Monument no. 32893. See associated HER 9462. Same as HER 1430.

Cross reference with HER 9462 and 9460. About 20 small cairns were recorded in 1963. Detailed survey shows that the cairnfield is more extensive and consists of 12 long cairns and 41 round cairns. The greatest concentration of cairns occurs on the SE.The site extends between the 190-240m contours on the S facing slope overlooking Brantrake Moss. The northernmost 5 cairns are on an exposed col, several have kerbs, and are most unlikey to have been associated with arable cultivation. On the lower slopes, to the E, more cairns may be sealed by peat.Detailed references below refer to the 1983 CLAU survey (S1065). The monument includes the earthworks and buried remains of a prehistoric cairnfield with an associated field system and two funerary cairns, a Romano-British farmstead consisting of two hut circles, two enclosures and an associated field system, and a post-medieval haematite mine. The site has been identified by a combination of field observation, limited excavation, aerial photography and field survey. The monument is located on the lower, south-facing slopes of Brantrake Crags overlooking Brantrake Moss and Black Beck, and represents evidence of the Bronze Age, Romano-British and post-medieval exploitation of this landscape. The prehistoric cairnfield is centred at approximately SD15109805 and includes over 60 circular and oval-shaped clearance cairns up to 1m high. The circular cairns measure between 1.5m and 4.5m in diameter while the oval-shaped cairns measure between 2.7m and 6.4m long by 1.5m to 5.4m wide. The field system associated with the cairnfield is located towards the south western end of the monument, centred at approximately SD15019795, and includes three lengths of stone bank or wall partially enclosing an area devoid of cairns which is considered to originally have been a field. Nearby are three short lengths of irregularly-shaped walling of uncertain function. Adjacent to these walls are two funerary cairns. The southern cairn measures approximately 12m long by 8m wide and up to 1m high with a stone kerb and disturbed centre revealing a stone cist within which the deceased's body or ashes would have been placed. The northern cairn measures approximately 7.5m in diameter and up to 1m high and is partially surrounded by a shallow ditch. The Romano-British settlement consists of the remains of two stone-walled but circles, one located at SD15149804, the other a short distance to the north east at SD15179808. The western but has an entrance on its south eastern side and a small annexe on its north eastern side, while the eastern but has entrances on the south and north west sides and an annexe on the north side. The associated field system includes two stone-walled enclosures adjacent to the huts; the western enclosure being roughly triangular in plan with internal dimensions of 15.4m by 11.5m and an entrance on the south entrance on the north east side. To the north east of this group of huts and enclosures are the fragmentary remains of numerous lengths of stone bank or wall which may originally have formed a large enclosure. Limited excavation of this wall during the 1960s indicated that it was constructed at some time between 200-580 AD. Further evidence of the field system comes from an aerial photograph which clearly shows areas of past ploughing on the hillslope above and to the north west of the Romano-British settlement. The remains of a post-medieval haematite mine are located at SD15039811 and consists of a trench dug into the hillside which led to a now blocked adit or level. Two spoil heaps are associated with the adit; one lies adjacent while the other runs along the contour a short distance below the adit (S905).

Monument Type: Monument

Monument Status: Scheduled Monument

ns:appellation.ns:name: Brown Rigg Prehistoric Cairnfield 375m E of Woodend Bridge

ns:description.ns:full:
Cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other) and enclosure (an area of land enclosed by a boundary ditch, bank, wall, palisade or other similar barrier) of Bronze Age date. Scheduled Ancient Monument no. 34965.

Thirty-three cairns were recorded. See article 'Cairn in the Birker and Ulpha Fell Area' by J. Cherry in the 1961 volume of C&WAAS (S2085 p. 13). See volume III of C&WAAS (S2341 p. 251). One was said to be 12 m in diam with a small secondary mound on its circumference. There is also an enclosure 7.6 m in diam (S1939). According to Crawford & George there are approx fifteen true cairns and several natural outcrops to which material has possibly been added (S1116 p. 50). The CLAU Survey 1982/3 identified a group of 7 cairns centred at SD18251 96277 (see GIS). They probably correspond to this HER record. However, there is no text information available and an exact description is impossible (S1065). The monument includes Brown Rigg prehistoric cairnfield 375m east of Woodend Bridge. It is.located on unenclosed land on Ulpha Fell, east of a stream draining Sike Moss, and represents Bronze Age exploitation of this landscape. The cairnfield includes a group of seven circular clearance cairns up to 0.4m high and measuring between 2.3m and 5.8m in diameter. Two of these cairns have traces of kerbinq around their edges (S905).

Monument Type: Monument

Monument Status: Scheduled Monument

A small primary type of cairnfield near Whillan beck. Most of the cairns are in a poor condition and ill-defined, with small stones protruding from the turf (S1914). Bronze Age cairnfield recorded in The National Trust Sites and Monuments Record (S2873).

ns:description.ns:full:
A cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other) of unknown date.

A small primary type of cairnfield, on a moderate sloped area of moorland near Burnmoor Tarn. They are relatively large, but non-prominent. There is no evidence of any stone banks and there are no significant alignments (S1914). Site recorded in The National Trust Sites and Monuments Record as a Bronze Age cairnfield. The database entry largely reproduces the details of the cairnfield from the earlier survey (S2873).

ns:description.ns:full:
Just above Mosedale Beck can be seen a cleared area of stones, many have been deposited in heaps as a cairnfield (group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other. Use for instances where the majority are clearance cairns) along the edge of a small gully to the North. While other stones have been piled up against large boulders in the fields.

Located above Mosedale Beck is a cleared section of hillside, many of the stones have been deposited along the edge of a small gully. To the North of this some stones have been piled against large boulders in the field (Wasdale Head Notebook 2).

ns:description.ns:full:
Cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other), field system (a group or complex of fields which appear to form a coherent whole) and possible enclosure (an area of land enclosed by a boundary) of Bronze Age date. Scheduled Ancient Monument no. 32834.

A group of mounds from which stones protrude, located on a SW facing slope. A group of "larger" mounds is centred at SD128908. Traces of a wall running across the contours, and on both sides of the present road can be seen. See T. Clare's MA thesis site no. 396 (S1939). For more details see AM County Index (S904). The site is also included in Crawford & George's archaeological survey of Copeland (S1116 p. 52). CLAU Survey of Corney Fell in 1984 identified a much larger area of cairns, lynchets and banks, which is now reflected on the G.I.S. Other cairnfields adjacent include HERs 1431, 1404, 31007, 31008 and 31009 (S1915). The site forms part of an extensive area of cairnfields, field systems, hut circles and a farmstead. For full details see scheduling. A third cairnfield (SAM 32834/002 ) lies to the north of Buckbarrow Bridge West cairnfield and is centred at approximately SD13039068. It is also crossed by the minor road and includes over 60 clearance cairns up to 0.45m high and varying between 2.2m in diameter to 8.9m long by 4.8m wide. Within this cairnfield are remains of a field system consisting of five lengths of stone walling which mark the northern edge of the cairnfield and an L-shaped length of walling interpreted as part of an enclosure (S905). This site was also located by Pete Rodgers in February 2005 (S1836).

ns:description.ns:full:
This expansive area has several cairns scattered amidst tumbled stone. The site is located on the bottom of the hillside inside the intake. To the southwest is Wast Water and to the South is Lingmell Gill.

Situated in the southern end of a large field are numerous cairns, these are amid a general scatter of stones. Many of the cairns are turfed over, most measure between 3m to 4m in diameter. The cairnfield is located on the bottom of the hillside within the intake walls (Wasdale Head Notebook 3).

ns:appellation.ns:name: Cairnfield and Associated Field System 880m SE of High Corney

ns:description.ns:full:
Cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other) and field system (a group or complex of fields which appear to form a coherent whole) of Bronze Age date. Scheduled Ancient Monument no. 32837.

Site identified from vertical aerial photographs taken as part of the CLAU VAP Project in 1983 and field observation undertaken 22 April 1983. The site is comprised of 16 badly defined cairns, largely composed of small stones, remains of wall follows slope (S1069). Also see article 'Plotting of Archaeological Sites from Vertical aerial Photographs: An Interim Report' by V.E. Turner in the 1984 volume of C&WAAS (S1868 p. 270-274). The site was revisited as part of the CLAU survey of Charlesground Gill in 1989. The site comprised of a group of cairns, located on a natural terrace with a gentle gradient, which are evidently contained by the natural topography. To the south is a scarp slope formed by Charlesground Gill and to the west there is a fairly sharp break of slope onto lower lying ground. To the east the ground rises gradually and the cairns appear to peter out in this direction. Generally the cairns are fairly well defined but they are not uniform in size or in distribution. The majority of the cairns have fairly prominent profiles but range in size from small to moderately large. It is a fairly concentrated group of cairns, especially towards the western end of the group, adjacent to the slope. There is a possible alignment of large, well defined cairns at the western extent of the cairnfield, which may define the area; there is no obvious alignment at the southern edge of the cairnfield, adjacent to Charlesground Gill. The concentration of the cairns in these areas may well be due to the topography. At the western end of the group, where the cairns are adjacent to the break of slope the terrain is more uneven and there is a slight dip in the ground just before and parallel to the break of slope, this area is poorly drained and contains areas of marshy ground and tussocks of grass. Many of the component cairns are generally large and fairly well defined with prominent profiles; however there are also some smaller cairns, concentrated around the southern and eastern edges of the cairnfield. To the east the cairns almost peter out as the ground rises gradually. The line of cairns at the western side probably refelcts the adjacent line of break of slope. It is a basic form of cairnfield, but the possible presence of cultivation plot that its original pastoral function was superceded by cultivation (S1919). The monument includes a small prehistoric cairnfield and associated field system and includes a group of 30 oval shaped clearance cairns measuring between 1.2m to 7.4m long by 1.2m to 6.9m wide and up to 0.55m high. Some of the cairns form alignments which are interpreted as representing the line of old field boundaries in which sporadic patches of stone clearance were piled against fences or hedges. One of the cairn alignments forms the western boundary of the cairnfield, while two other parallel alignments of cairns functioned as prehistoric field boundaries and run downslope approx 12m apart. The field between these two boundaries has been deliberately cleared of surface stone in order to facilitate unhindered use of the plough during agricultural cultivation (S905).

Monument Type: Monument

Monument Status: Scheduled Monument

ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:description.ns:full:
Cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other) and enclosure (an area of land enclosed by a boundary) of Bronze Age date. Scheduled Ancient Monument no. 32884.

80 cairns are recorded on the S slope of the "Seat." Most are on dry slopes, but some are on the flat, moist ground. Also present are a sub-rectangular enclosure with sides over 30 m long and other stretches of tumbled walling. See article 'Cairns in Birker Fell and Ulpha Fell Areas' by J. Cherry in the 1961 volume of C&WAAS (S2085 p. 12, S1361). See the C&WAAS Regional Groupos Report by Hyam (S2003 p. 19). The site is included in T. Clare's MA thesis as site no. 378 (S1939) and George & Crawford's Archaeological Survey of Copeland (S1116 p. 48). The digital data from the CLAU Survey of the area in 1982 and 1983 confirms a group of cairns and a rectangular enclosure. There is no text information accompanying the digital data, therefore exact descriptions are impossible (S1065). This appears to be the site covered by part 1 of SAM 32884. See scheduling details (S905).

Monument Type: Monument

Monument Status: Scheduled Monument

ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:description.ns:full:
Site of a cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other) of Bronze Age date.

More than 20 relatively prominent and well defined cairns, each measuring c3m in diameter, and up to 0.30m high. A long bank measuring 2m wide, 0.30m high extends east-west through the area, this like the cairns is relatively decayed, suggesting that it may be contemporary with the cairnfield The cairns and bank are located on an area of well drained ground, forming a natural terrace above an extensive area of mire. Though there was no evidence of a field system beyond the identified bank, the area seemed to have potential for agriculture in contrast with the surrounding landscape. This site was located during field survey undertaken by LUAU in 1995/6. Site No. H2 (S1931). In 2006 the results of a field survey in the area were published in C&WAAS. This article highlighted the possibility of new sites and offered new interpretations regarding spatial arrangements of sites around Moor Divock (S1812 p. 1-17).

Monument Type: Monument

ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:description.ns:full:
Cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other) of Bronze Age date. Scheduled Monument no. 1007235.

Scattered cairnfield of 15-20 small cairns up to 0.5 m high and 2m across. Some are quite well preserved, but the area is forested and some are overgrown with trees. Scheduled as SAM 76a. See also HER 3714, a bloomery site within same area (S904). Note: volume III of C&WAAS p. 28 was checked but does not relate to this site. A small cairnfield identified on an area of flat, forested ground. The cairnfield comprises a relatively dense group of 16 cairns and 3 stone banks. The cairns vary in size but most are medium sized, moderately defined and comprise medium to large stone. There are 3 larger cairns on the eastern side of the group, which are significantly more prominent than the others of the group. The size of the component stones is larger and may suggest that these were the product of a different episode of stone clearance. The 3 stone banks appear to define the edges of a narrow hollow way running north/south through the group. The group is in a reasonable state of preservation (S1887). Recorded as 'EF1 - Smithy Beck' within the LUAU final report (S1888). The site is included in T. Clare's MA thesis as site no.184 (S1939). George Crawford visited the site in April 1978 (S2097). The scheduled area has now be revised and has been designated a new number: 1007235 (S905)

Monument Type: Monument

Monument Status: Scheduled Monument

ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:appellation.ns:name: Cairnfield at Whin Garth - Bleng Forest

ns:description.ns:full:
Site of a cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other) of Bronze Age date.

LUAU Survey nos 447 - 495. The cairnfield is on fairly flat, slightly undulating terrain; it is unimproved but enclosed moorland. There is dense grass and moss which obscures the definition of the cairns. The cairns are fairly standard small cairns, some of them are slightly prominent but they usually have a regular, circular shape. There is no stone visible on the surface (because of dense vegetation cover), but probing invariably reveals stone close to the surface. By contrast probing the adjacent ground, stone is found at a much greater depth. The cairns are evidently genuine, despite their poor definition. The distribution of the cairns is essentially random, there do not appear to be any significant alignments. It would appear to be a primary form of cairnfield. The ground is threatened by forestry planting but was intact and undisturbed when visited (20-3-1992). See LUAU survey for more details of individual cairns and plans (S1564). In November 1993, Lancaster University Archaeological Unit (LUAU), at the request of the Lake District National Park Authority (LDNPA) and with financial assistance from Forest Enterprise and LDNPA, undertook a watching brief in advance of forestry planting at Blengdale Forest, near Gosforth, Cumbria. This followed on from a full topographic survey undertaken by LUAU in 1989 as part of the Lake District National Park Survey (S1564). The fieldwork comprised the examination of mounds and hollows that were excavated in preparation for tree planting. The aim of the watching brief was to record any artefact scatters or cairns exposed by the 'mounding' process. The survey data was incorporated into the archive of the 1989 survey and the locational information was superimposed within a CAD system onto the digitised plans of the earlier survey. The watching brief recovered only a small, prehistoric lithic assemblage, but identified a much larger quantity of clearance cairns. The results compliment the earlier survey and highlight the archaeological importance of the site (LUAU).

ns:description.ns:full:
This site is a number of cairns as a cairnfield (group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other. Use for instances where the majority are clearance cairns) formed around several boulders along the sloping fellside, these remains are of unknown date.

This area has several cairns around several boulders, this site is probably associated with the deposited stones in the gully (National Trust site 21809*0) (Wasdale Head Notebook 2).

ns:description.ns:full:
A cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other) and a wall of Bronze Age date.

A group of over 100 cairns situated NE of the Seat. The larger cairns are to the S. All are circular except 2 which measure 9.2 m x 4.6 m. At the SW end of the site is a curved, grass-covered wall of rounded stones. Between it and another stone wall are 2 additional cairns. See article 'Cairns in the Birker Fell and Ulpha Fell Area' by J. Cherry in the 1961 volume of C&WAAS (S2085 p. 11-12). See T. Clare's MA thesis site no. 371 (S1939). The site is also included in Crawford and George's archaeological survey of Copeland (S1116 p. 51). See also HER 4779.

Monument Type: Monument

ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:appellation.ns:name: Cairnfield, High Pike Haw, Torver High Common

ns:description.ns:full:
A cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other) of Bronze Age date.

Five "bronze age cairns" recorded by NAS Gazetteer. See other sites within same hazard area (S1323). According to OS Index, 5 cairns were located amongst the bracken in 1957. They were constructed of loose unhewn stones and showed no traces of ditches or retaining circles of stones. A later inspector suggested the cairns are of the type associated with field clearance, but that 2 of them appeared to be natural features (S1361). A small cairnfield (11 in total) on moderate, uniformed sloped ground between two areas of crag and scree. There is an area of mire at the north-eastern edge of the cairnfield and some of the cairns are within it suggesting that the mire has expanded since the formation of the cairnfield. The cairns are generally well defined and slightly prominent. There is a line of clearance stone extending downslope which appears to be a stone bank and hence may define the edge of an agricultural area/plot. Unlike other cairnfields on Torver High Common, these cairns do not appear to be grouped away from the better quality land, instead they are loosely scattered all over the area. There is, however, one cairn that is clearly deposited on unusable ground, against a massive boulder. There is one large cairn which is prominent (0.5m in height and 7.3m in diam., at SD26533 95182). It has a regular, rounded profile and has a regular circular shape defined by some larger stones around the edge which may be elements of a kerb. It is very distinct from the other cairns of this group, it is not a typical clearance cairn and may be funerary in function, however, it is not in a prominent location. This site was identified during a LUAU survey of Torver High Common in 1994 (S1893).

Monument Type: Monument

ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:appellation.ns:name: Cairnfield, etc S of Eller How, Burnmoor

ns:description.ns:full:
Cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other), funerary cairn (a stony mound containing or concealing deliberately deposited human remains), standing stone and three banks of Bronze Age date. Scheduled Ancient Monument no. 23699.

The monument includes a small cairnfield within which there are 11 cairns, one funerary cairn, one standing stone and 3 stone banks. It is located on a high point at the S end of a small plateau S of Eller How and lies within a large area of open moorland, Burnmoor, which contains an abundance of prehistoric remains. The site is crossed by the main footpath linking the Eskdale and Wasdale valleys and is visible from considerable distances in all directions. The slightly elevated dome on which it lies enables the site to drain naturally rendering it the only dry spot in the area. Of the 11 cairns within the cairnfield, 7 are sub-circular and range between 2.6m -6.5m long by 2.3m -5.4m wide and 0.15 - 0.35m high; 3 are circular and measure between 2.6m -3.5m in diam and 0.15m - 0.25m high, and one is ovoid, 3.3m long x 2.8m wide and 0.15m high. Two of the sub-circular cairns are kerbed with boulders. The funerary cairn lies a short distance to the W of the path and measures 13m long x 7.3m wide and up to 1.1m high. To the S of the funerary cairn there is the base of a rectangular standing stone, now broken, but measuring 0.6m high and embedded in stone packing. N of the funerary cairn there are 3 separate lengths of stone bank, 2 lying to the W of the path and one to the east. These measure 40m, 29m and 35m respectively and are 2-3m wide x 0.25m - 0.35m high. They are interpreted as part of the field system indicated by the cairnfield. The various elements of the monument survive reasonably well. The monument contains a number of differing features and illustrates well the diversity of monument classes which can be found within a cairnfield. It lies close to other prehistoric monuments on Burnmoor and thus indicates the importance of this area in prehistoric times. The funerary cairn lies adjacent to the main path linking 2 valleys - a feature unparalleled elsewhere within the Lake District National Park - and will contain undisturbed archaeological deposits within the mound and upon the old land surface. Scheduling includes a 10m boundary around the archaeological features, considered to be essential for the monuments support and preservation (S904, S905). See the Inventory of ancient monuments in Cumberland in the 1923 volume of C&WAAS (S1905 p. 265) and the OS Index (S1361). The site is included in T. Clare's MA thesis as site no. 297 (S1939) and George & Crawford's Archaeological Survey of Copeland (1116 p. 38). Also see 'The Gosforth District: Its Antiquities and Places of Interest' by Parker (S1364 p. 103-104). Site recorded within The National Trust Sites and Monuments Record, summarising previous knowledge - as above - of the site (S2873). Included in Regional Archaeological Audit (S5350).

Monument Type: Monument

Monument Status: Scheduled Monument

ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:description.ns:full:
Cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other), enclosure (an area of land enclosed by a boundary ditch, bank, wall, palisade or other similar barrier), five stone circles containing funerary cairns (stony mounds containing or concealing deliberately deposited human remains), six stone banks, two stone walls, a lynchet (large step cut into a field on a hill slope built deliberately to form a flat area which is easier to farm) and short length of trackway of Bronze Age date. Scheduled Ancient Monument no. 23700. For more detail on the stone circles see HER nos. 31711 - 31715.

The monument includes a large cairnfield located around the Brat's Moss area of Burnmoor at the W side of a large area of open moorland which contains an abundance of prehistoric remains. Within the cairnfield are a number of other monuments including a prehistoric enclosure, 5 stone circles each containing funerary cairns, 6 stone banks, 2 stone walls, a lynchet and a short length of trackway. The cairnfield contains approx 403 cairns. Some are round in shape and range in diam between 1.35m - 6.9m and 0.1m - 0.65m high, some are oval in shape, ranging between 2.9m long x 1.6m wide and 10.25m long x 3.9m wide and 0.1m - 0.9m high. Of the 5 stone circles Brat's Hill is largest with approx 42 stones forming an irregular circle with an average diam of 30.4m. There are 5 funerary cairns within the circle and 2 further stones. There is an outlying stone a short distance to the NW. NW of this circle are White Moss E and White Moss SW stone circles, the former 16.2m in diam with 11 stones forming the circle and a funerary cairn at the centre, the latter is 16.6m diam and has 14 stones and a funerary cairn at the centre. S and E of these stone circles is a long dog- legged length of stone bank beyond which is a sub-rectangular enclosure , max 50m x 30m internally. E of this is a short stone wall and a short length of trackway. In the N part of the cairnfield are 2 more stone circles, Low Long- rigg NE and Low Longrigg SW. The former is 21.7m x 20.4m and has 15 stones forming an irregular circle and contains 2 funerary cairns. The latter is 15.2m in diam, has 9 stones and a central funerary cairn. To the SW are 2 lengths of stone bank aligned SW-NE which separate 2 groups of cairns within the main cairnfield. To the E a wall aligned NW-SW also separates sub-groups of cairns. At the NE side of the complex are 3 banks, possibly lynchets. There is another lynchet S of Brat's Hill circle. The complex survives well. It contains a developed cairnfield and the most complex and diverse group of prehistoric monument classes to be found on Burnmoor. Together these individual monuments represent evidence of long term management and exploitation of the Bronze Age landscape on Burnmoor and indicate the importance of this area in prehistoric times. Scheduling includes a 2 metre boundary around the archaeological features, considered to be essential for the monument's support and preservation (S905). See the Inventory of ancient monuments in Cumberland in the 1923 volume of C&WAAS (S1905 p. 265). See T. Clare's MA thesis site nos 292-296 (S1939). See the CBA Archaeology Newsbulletin volume 10 May 1975 p. 10-11 (S1043). The site is also included in Crawford & George's archaeological survey of Copeland (S1116 p. 37). See publications 'The Stone Circles of the British Isles' by A. Burl (S1028 p. 60, 63-65, 342-3), 'Ancient Burial Mounds of England' by Ginsell (S1190 p. 244), Megalithic Sites in Britain' by Thom (S1432 p. 52-3, 60, 64-65, 96, 99, 138), 'The Gosforth District: Its Antiquities and Places of Interest' by Parker (S1364 p. 103, 217) and 'A Guide to Prehistoric England' by Nicholas (S1433). See the Proceedings of the Society of Antiquaries of London volume 3 p. 225-6 and volume 12 (2nd series) p. 91-92 (S1380). See CLAU 1984 site catalogue for further details of each individual monument. An enclosure at NY17533 02963 is now SMR No. 31710. The stone circles on Burnmoor have been allocated separate HERs 31711 - 31715 (S1914). The site is recorded in LUAU archaeological survey 2000, but no new data given (S1892). The site is visible on aerial photographs from the CLAU collection (S923). A funerary cairn was recorded by Peter Rodgers in May 2002 to the south-west of White Moss Stone Circle (S1825). For details of archaeological investigation at this site see the NMR excavation index 646088 (S1347). Site recorded within The National Trust Sites and Monuments Record, summarising much of the previously available - as above - sources. The individual components of the cairnfield and related sites have been recorded separately and/or grouped together by The Trust (S2873). The site includes enclosures, five 5 stone circles and funerary cairns around around the Brat's Moss area of Burnmoor at the western side of a large area of open moorland with an abundance of prehistoric remains. Other monuments include six stone banks, two stone walls, a lynchet, and a short length of trackway. The cairnfield contains approximately 403 cairns, ranging in size from 1.35 to 6.90 metres in diameter and 0.10 to 0.65 metres high. Oval cairns are also present. Of the five stone circles Brat's Hill is the largest with approximately 42 stones forming an irregular circle with an average diameter of 10.4 metres. Stone circles also lie as White Moss northeast and White Moss southwest stone circles; one with a funerary cairn at the centre. A long dog-legged length of stone bank and walls are recorded. In places as parallel stone banks aligned with the contours and may have functioned as lynchets. The large number of features have been recorded in previous work, e.g. S1361. Recording work by The National Trust itself has recorded the groupings of the area (S2955, 09.01.1998 and by P D Claris 1985, S2884). Included in Regional Archaeological Audit (S5350).

Monument Type: Monument

Monument Status: Scheduled Monument

ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:description.ns:full:
A small cairnfield of Bronze Age date. Included within Scheduled Ancient Monument no. 35013.

There is a small group of 5 clearance cairns, which are in poor condition, ill-defined with small stones protruding from the turf (S1916). Within SAM 35013 with SMR No.s 3978/7769/31031 and 31032. The scheduled monument includes a prehistoric cairnfield, ring cairn, hut circle and field system. It is located on the east facing gently-sloping fellside north of a minor road across Corney Fell and represents Bronze Age exploitation of the landscape. The cairnfield consists of over 200 round and oval-shaped clearance cairns up to 0.6m high; the round cairns measuring between 2m - 6.6m in diameter, the oval-shaped cairns measuring between 3.3m - 9.5m long by 1.9m - 6m wide. At SD1766 8972 there is a ring cairn consisting of a well-defined circle of stones 8.25m in diameter and up to 0.3m high surrounding a flattish, largely stone-free centre. At SD1731 8993 there are the remains of a hut circle (SMR No. 31031). Associated with these features are faint traces of a field system formed by fragments of enclosures and stone banks or walls. At SD1744 8998 there are the southern and eastern walls of a small enclosure, while further south at SD1754 8985, there is a discontinuous stone bank defining the western and northern boundaries of a probable D-shaped enclosure devoid of cairns. A third, smaller three sided enclosure is situated at SD1762 8975. Three lengths of stone bank or wall are found close to the southern end of the cairnfield; one about 70m long marks the southern limit of the cairnfield while another, about 20m long and well-defined, lies beyond the south western limit of the cairnfield (S905). Site recorded in The National Trust Sites and Monuments Record. The database entry gives details of each cairn from the earlier survey work carried out (S2873).

Monument Type: Monument

Monument Status: Scheduled Monument
ns:description.ns:summary: <b>A small cairnfield of Bronze Age date. ...

ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:appellation.ns:name: Cairns and Enclosure on The Rigg, Banniside

ns:description.ns:full:
Cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other) of Bronze Age date. Scheduled Ancient Monument no. 58.

Mounds and raised heaps of stone of varying size, some less than 0.9 m in diam. The latter tend to be no more than a few stones piled together. A large mound at SD27689625 appears to have been dug. At SD27669601 there are the remains of a circular enclosure formed by a bank of stones, ca 15 m in diam. This feature has a separate OS No. SD29NE07, see card in SMR file (S1361, S1048). See volume III of C&WAAS (S2341 p. 254). The area is now largely covered in bracken according to T. Clare and the site is numbered 400 in the MA thesis (S1939). The site was visited by J & B Trant in 1978 (S2268). See also SMR 3219 which may be the same site. AM and SMR nos refer to 58f, but AM County nos 58d,e,g,h are probably also under this SMR no. See also SMR 1607,1608,1609 (S904). An extent has been plotted in the GIS layer following the inclusion of the information from the LUAU Survey of Torver High Common 1994. It incorporates the scheduling 58g. The area includes three large cairns on top of a broad ridge and a small cairnfield to the east on a narrow terrace. Two of the large cairns on the ridge are clearly Bronze Age type funerary monuments. The other is smaller and its interpretation as a funerary monument is open to question. It is not well-defined, but comprises large amounts of stone and is relatively prominent. At SD27685 96244 is an extremely prominent and very large, round cairn (11.5m x 10.7m x 0.6m), with some large stones around the western edge which may be exposed elements of a kerb. It has a shallow central depression, probably the result of antiquarian disturbance. At SD27730 96298 is a relatively small, but very prominent kerbed cairn (6.8m x 5.6m x 0.5m). It is well defined with large stones around the western and southern edges. Again it has a central depression, probably the result of antiquarian disturbance. Both are funerary monuments. To the east is a small cairnfield. The main terrace comprises good agricultural land and the cairn distribution reflects a need to maximise the available ground. The size and form of the cairns varies, but they are mainly well-defined, prominent and relatively large (S1893, S1743). The site was visited by Pete Rodgers in December 2001. He noted that two of the Bronze Age funerary cairns were were much reduced in size by stone robbing (S1819).

Monument Type: Monument

Monument Status: Scheduled Monument

ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:appellation.ns:name: Cairns and Stone Bank at Hodgewife Well

ns:description.ns:full:
A linear bank (linear or curvilinear construction of earth, turf and stone, often, but not always accompanied by a ditch), a round cairn (a roughly hemispherical mound constructed primarily of stones, normally containing or covering one or more human burials) and five clearance cairns (an irregularly constructed, generally unstructured, mound of stones, often circular, and normally a by product of field clearance for agricultural purposes) of Bronze Age date. Scheduled Ancient Monument no. 35012.

There is a discontinuous, linear stone bank, defined by short small sections of bank and longer bank. A round cairn in good condition is fairly well defined with small and medium stones protruding from the turf and a slight depression at the centre. 5 clearance cairns are ill-defined and in poor condition (S1916). The scheduled monument includes a prehistoric cairnfield and linear boundary on Thwaites Fell immediately north of Hodgewife Well which represents Bronze Age exploitation of this landscape. The cairnfield lies on fairly level ground and consists of six round and oval-shaped clearance cairns measuring between 3.5m to 8m in diameter and up to 0.5m high. Running to the north of the cairnfield the linear boundary consists of a discontinuous low stone bank or wall 1m - 3m wide and 0.1m high which can be traced over a distance of at least 350m. It is aligned north west - south east and its longest continuous length can be seen running down the east facing hillslope. It is more fragmentary on boggy flatter ground where it may have become partly obscured by vegetation growth (S905). Site recorded in The National Trust Sites and Monuments Record (S2873).

Monument Type: Monument

Monument Status: Scheduled Monument

ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:description.ns:full:
Cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other) of Bronze Age date. Scheduled Ancient Monument no. CU 59.

Group of cairns and other associated features including walling and a possible structure. 5 cairns varying in diam from 3-6 m, up to a maximum height of 0.8 m.1 cairn, with a diam of 6 m, 0.7 m high, has a kerb with 3 larger boulders remaining in situ. A small stretch of drystone walling is associated with the above, 4 m long, 0.3 m high. Also associated is an irregular stone spread 6 x 4 m, 0.4 m high, and could represent a structure. The features lie on stony ground with rock outcrops (S904). Site recorded by Peter Rodgers, who describes three cairns 10-12m in diameter, two of which had been disturbed. This site was located by Pete Rodgers during site visits in November and December 2000 (S1844).

Monument Type: Monument

Monument Status: Scheduled Monument

ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:appellation.ns:name: Cairns on Throng Moss 700ft SW of the Reservoir, Torver

ns:description.ns:full:
Cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other) of Bronze Age date. Scheduled Ancient Monument no. 121.

The "cairns" consist of 2 mounds from which stones protrude and 5 grassed heaps of stone (S1361). The latter group is arranged in an arc approx concentric with the contours. Most of the "cairns" appear to have been disturbed according to T. Clare's MA thesis site no. 423 (S1939). See volume III of C&WAAS (S2341 p. 245). AM County Index puts no at 9-10, situated on level ground with rising moorland to SW and to SE. Diameters between 3 and 7m, with max height of approx 0.3m. 2 of the largest at E end of group show signs of excavation (S904). The largest and most completely defined cairnfield on Torver Low Common. There are sixteen cairns randomly scattered around the site, most near the edge of the terrace, leaving a well cleared area in the centre. There is no evidence of any field systems or habitation platforms around the site so in that respect it is much like the others on the Common. However, the number of cairns and the size of some indicate a far more intensive clearance regime at this site in comparison with the others. The largest three cairns all have central hollows, indicating more recent disturbance, perhaps by antiquarians believing them to be funerary monuments. This does not appear to be the case, as they are spatially associated with clearance cairns and are irregular. They are insufficiently defined to indicate a funerary function and their locations are not prominent. This site was located during a field survey conducted by LUAU in 1995 (S1894).

Monument Type: Monument

Monument Status: Scheduled Monument

ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:appellation.ns:name: Cairns on and 1/2 mile S of Water Crag

ns:description.ns:full:
Cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other) and associated field system (a group or complex of fields which appear to form a coherent whole) of Bronze Age date. Scheduled Ancient Monument no. 32878.

A cairnfield centred at SD156974. Some cairns are 7.6 m in diam, others 3-6 ft diam. There are 5 "long" cairns 7.6-10.6 m wide (S1361). See also SMR 2699 which is scheduled as part of the same cairnfield (S904). According to the CLAU 1983 survey of Biker and Birkby Fells there are 285 cairns altogether. At SD1556 9725 there is a possible hut circle. It is in a sheltered position to the N of Water Crag and to the E are other possible hut platforms. It is c. 51 m from the cairnfield (S1065). The site is included in T, Clare's MA thesis as site no. 273 (S1939) and George & Crawford's Archaeological Survey of Copeland (S1116 p. 50). See article by Leech 'Cairns in the Birker Fell and Ulpha Fell Area' in the 1961 volume of C&WAAS (S2085 p. 7-8). Also see article 'Settlements a Groups of Small Cairns on Birkby and Birker Fells' by Leech in the 1983 volume of C&WAAS for site location and details (S1869 p. 15-23). This site originally formed part of SAM 82, but has now been separated out and given a separate scheduling number together with SMR 5349. The monument includes the earthworks and buried remains of a prehistoric cairnfield, associated field system and a hut circle. It is located to the east of Water Crag, on the plateau between Water Crag and Rough Crag, extends downslope southwards towards Devoke Water, and represents evidence of the Bronze Age exploitation of this landscape. The prehistoric cairnfield is centred at approximately SD15629738 and includes over 120 circular and oval-shaped clearance cairns up to 0.7m high. The circular cairns measure between 2.2m to 6.9m in diameter while the oval-shaped cairns measure between 3.4m to 9.1m long by 1.9m to 6.4m wide. The western extent of the cairnfield is marked by a short length of stone banking together with the crags below the summit of Water Crag. A field system associated with the cairnfield consists of a curvilinear enclosure centred at approximately SD15589726. Elsewhere within the cairnfield a number of cairn-free areas may indicate the former site of small field plots. On the north western side of the cairnfield, in a sheltered position at SD15489754, there is a platform containing the remains of a but circle 4.7m in diameter. Pollen cores taken from the sediments of nearby Devoke Water have revealed the changing vegetational history of this area over the last 5000 years and show episodes of forest clearance and a development of grassland during the prehistoric period. During one of these episodes most trees were cut down and were soon replaced by extensive grassland. This clearance is associated with the Bronze Age on the basis of its similarity to a clearance episode from Seathwaite Tarn 9km to the east, which has been scientifically dated to around 1000 BC (S905). Site visited on the 30/11/2011 (see images HER_2696#1-4). Some areas of the site are suffering from bracken infestation (S5197).

Monument Type: Monument

Monument Status: Scheduled Monument

ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:appellation.ns:name: Cairns, Bleaberry Haws, Torver High Common

ns:description.ns:full:
Cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other) of Bronze Age date.

Small cairns reported on a hillside. See volumes III (S2341 p. 254) and IX (S2347 p. 498) of C&WAAS. Clare could not locate the site in 1972 (S1939). A small group of four cairns on a broad natural terrace, which for the most part is well-drained, but has an undulating surface. The cairns are located around the periphery of the better land, presumably to maximise the available ground. They are slightly ill-defined but are clearly artificial in origin. This site was identified during a LUAU survey of Torver High Common in 1994 (S1893).

Monument Type: Monument

ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:appellation.ns:name: Cairns,Hut Circles at Junction R Calder/Whoap Beck

ns:description.ns:full:
Site of either a cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other) or hut circles (round houses indicated by the presence of a low, roughly circular bank of turf, earth or stone, which formed the base of the walls) of Bronze Age date. Scheduled Ancient Monument no. 79.

The AM County Index calls them 4 low stone cairns, but Crow says they may be hut circles. Scheduled as SAM 79d. See other related sites under same hazard no (S904).

Monument Type: Monument

Monument Status: Scheduled Monument

ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:appellation.ns:name: Clearance cairn southeast of Galleny Force, Borrowdale

ns:description.ns:full:
This small clearance cairn (an irregularly constructed, generally unstructured, mound of stones. Often, but not necessarily, circular. Normally a by product of field clearance for agricultural purposes) is built up against a large stone, it is situated southeast of Galleny Force. It is possible that this is a part of a cairnfield (A group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other) that associates all the surrounding cairns togeather.

This clearance cairn is heaped up against a boulder, there is no real distinct shape. The site is 1.5m in diametre and over 0.7m. The site is possibly apart of a cairnfield that associates the surrounding cairns (National Trust sites 22133*0, 22133*1 and 22133*2, and also 22134*0) with one another (Borrowdale Data Collection Sheets). This site is situated in Ordnance Survey field number 797.

Monument Type: Monument

ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:appellation.ns:name: Clearance cairns near Churn Hole on Pike Side Farm, Duddon

ns:description.ns:full:
This area of clearance cairns (irregularly constructed, generally unstructured, mound of stones. Often, but not necessarily, circular. Normally a by product of field clearance for agricultural purposes) is situated southeast of Churn Hole. Together the cairns make up a cairnfield (group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other. Use for instances where the majority are clearance cairns) area.

Area of clearance cairns that are likely to have been gathered together in order to improve the quality of the pasture in this area. It is possible that some small scale cultivation may have taken place in this area.

Monument Type: Monument

ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:appellation.ns:name: Corney Fell,Cairns 400 yds E of Buckbarrow Bridge

ns:description.ns:full:
Cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other) of Bronze Age date. Scheduled Ancient Monument no. 32839.

Cairns recorded here. They may be the cairns described on HER 1453 (awaiting clarification from HBMC). According to OS there are groups of cairns "near the enclosure on the Ulpha- Waberthwaite bridle path." There are more "cairns" than the 13 depicted on OS 6" map, but generally they are ill-formed heaps of stone, varying in diameter from 3.0 to 7.0 m. As such they would appear to be the result of stone clearance, although there are no formal field systems and only small pockets of clearance are evident (S1323). Also see article 'Plotting of Archaeological Sites from Vertical Aerial Photographs: An Interim Report' by V.E. Turner in the 1984 volume of C&WAAS (S1868 p. 270-274). A large cairnfield identified by the CLAU Survey. It is constrained by topography; mires defined the extent of the cairnfield, particularly to the west and north. The largest, compact group of cairns is in the north of this group. The cairns are monstrous, extremely prominent, very large and very irregular in places. They have regular, rounded profiles and comprise predominantly large and medium sized stones. They generally have well defined edges. Despite the size and prominence of the cairns, there is no serious case for suggesting that these are funerary monuments, due to their association with a large number of similarly large cairns, being adjacent to a mire and associated with a field system, it is evident they are large clearance cairns. One cairn is isolated from the group (SD1309592322) by a marshy area. To the south of this group is a significantly smaller and less prominent group of cairns. They are more widely spaced out and it is evident that considerably less clearance stone was removed from the adjacent ground. To the east is a group of cairns even smaller in size and less prominent than those in the rest of the group (S1919). Also see gazetteer for the Archaeological Survey of Copeland by George & Crawford in 1983 (S1116 p. 52). See Scheduling for details for this scheduled ancient monument (S904).

Monument Type: Monument

Monument Status: Scheduled Monument

ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:appellation.ns:name: Crosby Gill Prehistoric Cairnfield & Field System & a Dispersed Med Sment and Associated Lynchets

ns:description.ns:full:
Cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other) and associated field system (a group or complex of fields which appear to form a coherent whole) of Bronze Age date. There is also a dispersed settlement and associated lynchets (large steps cut into a field on a hill slope built deliberately to form flat areas which are easier to farm) of Medieval date. Scheduled Ancient Monument no. 34972.

40-50 cairns from 3.7-4.6 m were reported on the N,S and W sides of a small rectangular enclosure. There was a short portion of ruined wall to the S and ca 95 m SW was a circular enclosure of 30.8 m diam within which there were 4 cairns. See article 'Cairns in Birker Fell and Ulpha Fell Area' in the 1961 volume of C&WAAS (S2085 p. 14). The site is included in T. Clare's MA thesis as site no. 388 (S1939) and George & Crawford's Archaeological Survey of Copeland (S1116 p. 50). The CLAU digital data shows cairns, a rectangular enclosure and a circular enclosure further south. There is no text available which corresponds to this digital information (S1928). The monument includes the earthworks and buried remains of Crosby Gill prehistoric cairnfield and associated field system, and a dispersed medieval settlement and associated lynchets 450m west of Crosbythwaite. It is located on gently sloping enclosed land on the hillside west of Crosby Gill and represents evidence for the prehistoric and medieval exploitation of this landscape. The prehistoric cairnfield includes 28 circular and oval-shaped clearance cairns up to 0.9m high; the circular cairns measure between 2.lm to 7m in diameter while the oval-shaped cairns measure between 4.4m to 6.3m long by 2.3m to 4.9m wide. The associated prehistoric field system consists of two irregularly-shaped stone-banked enclosures. The northern of these enclosures is centred at SD18649507 and measures approximately 70m by 60m internally. The enclosure is open on its south east side and contains a semi-circular structure within its south western corner which has been partly disturbed by construction of a later building platform. This structure appears to have an entrance on its eastern side and may originally have been a small enclosure or a large hut circle. Internally there are three clearance cairns within the main prehistoric enclosure. A small ID'-shaped enclosure with an entrance on its eastern side is attached to the outer wall on the prehistoric enclosure's north east side; this enclosure may be an original feature or it may be associated with a later building platform constructed immediately adjacent and within the prehistoric enclosure. The southern prehistoric enclosure is centred at SD18559482 and measures approximately 90m by 60m internally. It has an entrance on its western side and contains three clearance cairns. A sub-rectangular annexe with an entrance on its western side is attached to the northern side of this enclosure. The dispersed medieval settlement includes six building platforms, each consisting of a rectangular terrace cut into the hillslope. The most prominent is located at SD18589509; adjacent to this building platform is a stone-walled enclosure measuring approximately 15 sq m with an entrance on its north side. Another building platform lies about 20m to the north of this enclosure while two more building platform are located about 30m to the south. The northern of these two building platforms lies immediately outside the western corner of the northern prehistoric enclosure, while the southern building platform partly overlies an earlier structure situated within the prehistoric enclosure's south western corner. Another building platform lies adjacent to the eastern wall of the prehistoric enclosure. The remaining building platform is situated at SD16619496 immediately east of a cluster of clearance cairns and short lengths of stone walling. Associated with the dispersed medieval settlement are strip lynchets characteristic of medieval cultivation. One of the lynchets is centred at about SD18559517 while a group of four lynchets are centred further downhill at about SD18659520 and run along the contour and across the hillslope. The boundary of a modern fir plantation is excluded from the scheduling, although the ground beneath it is included (S905).

Monument Type: Monument

Monument Status: Scheduled Monument

ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:appellation.ns:name: Four Funerary Cairns/Cairnfield on Threepow Raise, Askham

ns:description.ns:full:
Four funerary cairns (a stony mound containing or concealing deliberately deposited human remains) and a cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other) of Bronze Age date. Scheduled Ancient Monument no. 22541.

Traditionally 3 mounds, but at least 4, and there appear to be others. They are distinguished by their vegetation which is of better quality than the surrounding hillside. Three recorded as excavated. No finds other than charcoal. See T. Clare's MA thesis site no. 149 (S1939). See volumes III (S2341 p. 252) and VIII (S2346 p. 338) of C&WAAS. See article 'The antiquities of Shap, Westmoreland' by Simpson in volume 18 of the Archaeological Journal published in 1861 (S2591 p. 32). Also see article 'Tumuli on Three Pow Rise Moor Divock' in the 1935 volume of C&WAAS (S1908 p. 66-68). See the RCHM 1936 Westmorland (S1389 p. 27). See the NAS Gazetteer NY42SE11 (S1323 p. 12). One of mounds has an exposed cist Am Index 45r (S904). There appear to be several other mounds just outside this area which may be related. See also SMR 2942, 2944, 2961. Also hazard area SMR 2945. The monument includes four funerary cairns and a surrounding cairnfield on Threepow Raise. The funerary cairn situated on the summit of Threepow Raise includes an oval mound of largely turf-covered stones. The mound measures up to 0.55m high with max dimensions of 7.1m x 6.2m and has kerbing around the SW edge and the remains of a stone cist slightly E of centre. Approximately 55m to the ESE is an oval mound of partly turf-covered stones up to 0.2m high with max dimensions of 4.7m x 4.3m. This cairn has a central hollow in which remains of a small cist are visible. Approximately 65m SSW of the summit, on a slight rise between two areas of bog, is a flat-topped oval mound of largely turf-covered stones up to 0.5m high, with max dimensions of 5.3m x 4.7m. Approximately 55m to the SW, on the same slight rise, is an irregularly shaped mound of largely turf-covered stones. It is 0.3m high with max dimensions of 12.2m x 4.4m and has upright stones forming a kerb along its SW edge. The surrounding cairnfield includes 31 cairns and 2 stone banks. These cairns can be sub-divided into 4 groups; one group of 2 small cairns up to 0.2m high with max dimensions of 4.2m x 3.8m occupies the same slight rise between 2 areas of bog as described above. A second group of 19 cairns generally c.3m in diam and up to 0.3m high, together with 2 stone banks, are scattered around the gently graded slopes of Threepow Raise. A third group of 8 generally smaller cairns is located within a gully E of Elder Beck; and a fourth group of 2 small cairns is located W of Elder Beck. Limited excavation in 1935 of the funerary cairn and two cairns within the cairnfield, coupled with the antiquarian investigation of the cairn on the summit of Threepow Raise, indicate that the monument comprises two distinct elements; small clearance cairns around the lower slopes and a number of funerary cairns on the gently- sloped summit. The monument lies within an area of open fell rich in prehistoric monuments and thus indicates the importance of this area in prehistoric times and the diversity of monument types to be found here. Scheduling includes a 2 metre boundary around the archaeological features, considered to be essential for the monument's support and preservation (S905). LUAU Survey of Askham Fell (No.s 39 - 77 & 218, Plan No.s 3 & 4): the survey identified small groups of cairns and banks, which are described more fully in the catalogue (S84). For details of archaeological investigation at this site see the NMR Excavation Index 645677 (S1347). The site is visible on aerial photographs from the Cumbria County Council (S917) and Manchester University (S918) collections.

Monument Type: Monument

Monument Status: Scheduled Monument

ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:description.ns:full:
Cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other) of Bronze Age date.

Small cairns, grassed heaps of stones and a small circular enclosure with an internal diameter of 1.8 m. Varying opinion as to whether the cairns represent a BA cemetery or recent field clearance heaps (S1361). See volume III of C&WAAS (S2341 p. 254). See the Inventory of ancient monuments in Westmorland and Lancashire North of the Sands in the 1926 volume of C&WAAS (S2229 p. 44). See T. Clare's MA thesis site no. 306 (S1939). Site recorded within The National Trust Sites and Monuments Record. The steep hillside South of the River Duddon is covered with outcrop and scree. On a shoulder of the hill the outcrop is more scattered and the ground largely moorland pastures. On this pastures are several scatters of loose stone. These spreads are nearly circular in shape with diameters varying from 2.0 to 5.0 metres. Their regularity of shape suggest that they are the remains of robbed cairns although in their present state they cannot be certainly identified as such. In all seventeen of these circular spreads were located but be mutilated cairns. The slightness of the traces however prevented even tentative identification. Two of the group of probable cairns had distinguishing features:- 'A' This consists of a circle of loose stones with an overall diameter of 5.0 metres. The interior is clear of stones. The circle may be a robbed cairn or it may be the remains of a small hut or sheep shelter although there is no trace of an entrance. 'B' This spread of stones, 4.0 metres in diameter, incorporates a large slab measuring approximately 1.1 x 0.9 metres and resembling a cist cover. None of the features referred to had any traces of ditches or rebuilding circles (S1361, F1 1957). This whole assemblage of cairns, including those specifically noted by F1, appears to represent no more than random clearance, probably undertaken recently to improve the available pasturage. Certainly none is large enough to be a purpose-built sepulchral mound, nor is there any evidence of a field pattern (S1361, F1 1973), (S2873).

Monument Type: Monument

ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:description.ns:full:
Cairnfield of Bronze Age date.

Mounds from which stones protrude are located on a slight slope in a hollow between crags. See T. Clare's MA thesis (S1939).
