ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:appellation.ns:name: Great Crag prehistoric cairnfield and associated field system 710m south east of Birkerthwaite

ns:description.ns:full:
Site of a cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other) and an associated field system (a group or complex of fields which appear to form a coherent whole) and D-shaped enclosure (an area of land, in the shape of a D, enclosed by a boundary ditch, bank, wall, palisade or similar barrier) of Bronze Age date. Scheduled Ancient Monument no. 32887.

The data received from CLAU 1983 survey identifies a large enclosure surrounded by cairns. There is no text available at the moment, so exact identification is impossible (S1065). The monument includes Great Crag prehistoric cairnfield and associated field system, located on the col between Great Crag and Little Crag, 710m south east of Birkerthwaite. It represents Bronze Age exploitation of this landscape and includes 13 circular and oval-shaped clearance cairns up to 0.5m high. The circular cairns measure between 1.7m and 5.5m in diameter while the ovalshaped cairns measure between 2m to 6m long by 1m to 3.2m wide. Associated with the cairnfield is a field system consisting of a `D'-shaped enclosure measuring a maximum of about 90m by 70m which is crossed by a later drystone wall. There are gaps on the enclosure's north and north eastern sides which may have been entrances. The interior is devoid of features except for a single cairn. To the south of the enclosure there is a curvilinear length of stone wall or bank which, together with the south west wall of the enclosure, forms the boundary of an area which is devoid of cairns and may have originally been a field plot. The later drystone wall crossing the `D'-shaped enclosure is excluded from the scheduling, although the ground beneath it is included (S905). Photocopies in the HER file from the Friends of the Lake District Aerial Photograph Collection show the large enclosure (S1943).

Monument Type: Monument

Monument Status: Scheduled Monument
ns:description.ns:summary: <b>Site of a cairnfield (a group of cairns ...

ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:appellation.ns:name: Hare Gill Prehistoric Cairnfield, Settlement, etc. 715m SSE of Fisher Gate

ns:description.ns:full:
A cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other), hut circle settlement (a settlement consisting of several hut circles (round houses), either grouped together or dispersed) and an associated field system (a group or complex of fields which appear to form a coherent whole) of Bronze Age date. Scheduled Ancient Monument no. 32883.

A possible field system and cairns, first recorded from air photographs, were investigated during detailed survey in 1983 at Hare Gill. Walls on the NE facing slope above Hare Gill marking the limit of the bracken, together with a possible lynchet and curving wall, are possibly part of a field system. Abuting the curving wall on the SE is a rectangular enclosure. A cairnfield comprising 13 long cairns and 18 round cairns is contiguous with the enclosure and walls, but it is not certain whether the cairnfield is contemporary with them. There is also a shooting butt at SD1614 8682. See CLAU plan and catalogue for the 1982/3 survey of Birkby Fell for further information (S1065). The monument includes the earthworks and buried remains of Hare Gill prehistoric cairnfield, hut circle settlement and an associated field system located above Hare Gill on the east-facing slopes of Garner Bank, 715m SSE of Fisher Gate. It represents Bronze Age exploitation of this landscape and includes over 30 circular and oval-shaped clearance cairns, measuring up to 1.3m high, centred at SD16029850. The circular cairns measure between 1.2m to 4.8m in diameter while the oval-shaped cairns measure between 3m to 8m long by 1.5m to 4.6m wide. Associated with the cairnfield is a field system consisting of two stone banks or walls, each with an entrance, which form the northern and south western boundaries of the cairnfield and field system. A line of six stones also marks the south west limit of the field system. Elsewhere, at approximately SD16109847, there is a curvilinear stone wall or bank with an entrance on its south side which may originally have formed part of an enclosure. Another feature of the field system, and one considered to be an indicator of past arable cultivation, is a lynchet which runs north westsouth east through a cairn-free area in the northern half of the monument. Abutting the south east side of the curvilinear enclosure wall, at SD16099845, is a but circle settlement. It consists of a rectangular stone-walled enclosure sub-divided into two smaller rectangular enclosures by a cross wall, with each enclosure having an entrance on the south east side. The uphill enclosure is the more level and appears to contain the remains of a hut circle, while the adjoining lower enclosure appears sunken and is interpreted as a small stock pen (S905).

Monument Type: Monument

Monument Status: Scheduled Monument

ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:appellation.ns:name: Hesk Fell Pike Cairnfield, Enclosure, Lynchets

ns:description.ns:full:
Cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other) and linear boundary of Bronze Age date. Scheduled Ancient Monument no. 35015.

A group of 50-80 cairns situated in a stoney area of peat and heather. There are also the remains of an oval enclosure 77 x 46 m with additional groups of cairns to the N and S. One of the larger cairns appears to have been excavated. See article 'Cairns in Birker Fell and Ulpha Fell Area' by J. Cherry in the 1961 volume of C&WAAS (S2085 p. 14-15, S1361). The site is included in T. Clare's MA thesis as site no. 390 (S1939) and George & Crawford's Archaeological Survey of Copeland (S1116). The site is also visible on aerial photographs from the CLAU collection (S923). NAS Gazetteer mentions lynchets (S1323). Area surveyed by LDNPA and National Trust on 30/06/2002 with GPS kit. A large number of cairns and linear boundary were identified and recorded (S2212). The scheduled monument includes a prehistoric cairnfield and linear boundary on Hesk Fell. It is located on the south facing slope and represents Bronze Age exploitation of this landscape. It includes over 110 clearance cairns up to 0.5m high measuring between 2m - 6m in diameter. The linear boundary is formed by a low stone bank or wall up to 0.3m high and 2.5 m wide aligned north east - south west. It measures approximately 140m long and may be the continuation of a linear boundary running through the next field to the east. There is another short length of stone bank or wall aligned north west - south east on the boundary's north side (S905). Site recorded in The National Trust Sites and Monuments Record (S2873). This cairnfield is located on the lower fell land to the north-west of Pikeside Farm. The remains seem extensive and cover and area of at least 400m by 200m. A large number of cairns were recorded within the area of interest, along with what could perhaps be linear clearance, cultivation plots, routeways and house platforms. The remains are typical of other prehistoric, often Bronze Age, field systems known in the western valleys (S2953). Included in Regional Archaeological Audit (S5350).

Monument Type: Monument

Monument Status: Scheduled Monument

ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:appellation.ns:name: Hesk Fell Prehistoric Cairnfield, Funerary Cairn, Linear Boundary, Medieval Settlement &Field System

ns:description.ns:full:
Cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other), funerary cairn (a stony mound containing or concealing deliberately deposited human remains) and linear boundary of Prehistoric date. There is also a dispersed settlement and associated field system (a group or complex of fields which appear to form a coherent whole) of Medieval date. Scheduled Ancient Monument no. 34973.

Between 50-80 cairns recorded. One of the larger ones appears to have been dug. There is an oval enclosure ca 76 x 46m. See article 'Cairns in Birker Fell and Ulpha Fell Area' by J. Cherry in the 1961 volume of C&WAAS (S2085 p. 14-15). The site is included in T. Clare's MA thesis as site no. 390 (S1939) and Crawford's Archaeological Survey of Copeland (S1116 p. 55). The external boundary of the enclosure is a prominent, uniform, continuous dry stone wall. The construction comprises external revetting with small stone packing and the walls survive up to three courses in places. The entrances through the wall survive well, little collapse obscures the gap and there are substantial blocks of masonry on either side. They are however fairly narrow and are more appropriate for humans than stock. The surface within the enclosure is moderately sloping, well drained ground. It does not appear to have been improved; there are natural outcrops scattered around the area and there are no residual evidence of any cultivation activities. There is no evidence that the adjacent cairnfield ever extended across the boundary of the present enclosure, which may be an indication that the cairns are contemporary with the enclosure, or that the internal cairns were comprehensively robbed for the perimeter wall. In which case it is odd that the cairns on the outside of the wall were not also robbed. Within the enclosure there is an 'L' shaped wall, which comprises only a line of very large boulders. There is no evidence of internal terracing. The function is consistent with controlling stock, hence the unimproved internal ground and continuous, prominent external walls. There are 4 associated enclosures/huts, set into the wall of the main enclosure. Two (at SD1839594095 and SD18419410) are consistent with a stock control function, but the other two huts are internally terraced and were probably used as dwellings (at SD1841794095 and 1847994180). Further information is available in the CLAU Site Catalogue (S1921). The site is visible on aerial photographs from the CLAU collection (S923) and CLAU 1981 APO no 568 (SD19) 1:25,000 (S2392). The monument includes the earthworks and buried remains of Hesk Fell prehistoric cairnfield and funerary cairn, a linear boundary, and a dispersed medieval settlement and associated field system 840m west of Horseman Gate. it is located on gently sloping enclosed land on the south eastern slopes of Hesk Fell and represents prehistoric and medieval exploitation of this landscape. The earliest feature at this monument is a prehistoric cairnfield which includes over 70 circular and oval-shaped clearance cairns up to 0.5m high. The circular cairns measure between 1.9m to 6.6m in diameter while the oval-shaped cairns measure between 5.2m to 16.4m long by 1.3m to 4.9m wide. Towards the eastern end of the cairnfield, at SD18549403, there is what is interpreted as a prehistoric funerary cairn. It measures 6.6m in diameter by 0.6m high and has been disturbed at its centre by unrecorded investigation in the past. At an unknown date after the creation of the cairnfield a linear boundary consisting of nine lengths of stone bank or wall was built running, through the cairnfield on a north east-south west alignment for about 370m. During the medieval period a dispersed settlement was constructed consisting, of a large 'D'-shaped enclosure measuring about 114m by 86m internally, two huts and two small stock pens. The central part of the existing linear boundary was used as a wall for the D-shaped enclosure and at the two points where the enclosure wall and the linear boundary met, two single-roomed stone huts were constructed. The south western of these huts is rectangular in plan with an entrance leading from the D-shaped enclosure, while the slightly larger north eastern hut has an entrance leading from the adjacent hillside. The D-shaped enclosure has three narrow entrances, one adjacent to each of the huts, another on its eastern side. There are no signs of cultivation within this enclosure and despite its narrow entrances it is interpreted as a stock enclosure, with the associated structures considered to have been herdsmen's huts. on the opposite side of the linear boundary, adjacent to the south western hut, are two small enclosures interpreted as stock pens. The eastern stock pen has a single entrance on its north east side, while the western stock pen has two entrances, one giving access from the northern side of the linear boundary the other giving access from the southern side of the linear boundary (S905). Site recorded in The National Trust Sites and Monuments Record, where the settlement remains are thought to be of Later Prehistoric-Romano-British date. The cairnfield is thought to be Bronze Age, number 20012 (S2873). Included in Regional Archaeological Audit (S5350).

Monument Type: Monument

Monument Status: Scheduled Monument

ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:description.ns:full:
Cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other) of Bronze Age date.

15 grassed heaps of stones are located on a small shoulder above a stream. See T. Clare's MA thesis site no. 394 (S1939). The site is also included in Crawford & George's archaeological survey of Copeland (S1116 p. 55).

Monument Type: Monument

ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:appellation.ns:name: Howthwaite, Carrock Fell Cairnfield, Hut Circle

ns:description.ns:full:
A cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other), field system (a group or complex of fields which appear to form a coherent whole), two enclosures (areas of land enclosed by a boundary ditch, bank, wall, palisade or other similar barrier), a funerary cairn (a stony mound containing or concealing deliberately deposited human remains) and a hut circle (a round house indicated by the presence of a low, roughly circular bank of turf, earth or stone, which formed the base of the walls) of Bronze Age date. Scheduled Ancient Monument no. 34958.

Group of cairns and possible hut circles including 2 saucer-shaped depressions near the fork of the old and new roads. One depression was excavated and consisted of a loosely piled circle of stones, traces of burning- a possible hut site. Howthwaite stone cairn at NY34443556 also excavated and was a roughly circular cairn of large stones. No burial found, only a worked flint, slag. Some of the cairns may be connected with mining and many of those recorded by Barker can no longer be located (S1361). The site is listed by Challis and Harding as an extensive Bronze Age settlement (S1055 p. 43). For details regarding excavation in 1934-5 by Barker see articles in the 1934 (S1910 p. 107-108), 1935 (S1908 p. 174) and 1950 (S1909 p. 201-202) volumes of C&WAAS. The scheduled area includes the following: The monument includes the earthworks and buried remains of Weasel Hills prehistoric cairnfield, associated field system, hut circle and funerary cairn immediately north and north west of High Wath Ford. It is located on gently sloping ground on Caldbeck Common and lies either side of the minor road between Mungrisedale and Caldbeck. The monument represents Bronze Age exploitation of this landscape and is sub-divided into two separate areas of protection. The prehistoric cairnfield is centred at approximately NY34733535 and consists of over 60 circular and oval-shaped clearance cairns up to 0.6m high. The circular cairns measure between 2.8m to 7.5m in diameter while the oval-shaped cairns measure between 2.8m to 16.5m long by 1.2m to 8.9m wide. A field system associated with the cairnfield lies either side of the minor road. To the west of the road the field system consists of a large horseshoe-shaped enclosure, centred at NY34683552, which is open on its south side and includes numerous lengths of stone bank which may have formed field boundaries, and two lynchets. To the east of the road the field system consists of a small horseshoe-shaped enclosure, three parallel lengths of stone wall each about 130m apart running downhill, and a number of short lengths of stone banks and lynchets running across the hillslope. At NY34643635 there are the remains of a hut circle about 7m in diameter, while at the eastern edge of the monument at NY35073536 there is an oval-shaped funerary cairn measuring llm north-south by 10m east-west and up to 1.lm high on its downslope east side. All modern field boundaries and the surfaces of all modern tracks are excluded from the scheduling, although the ground beneath these features is included (S905).

Monument Type: Monument

Monument Status: Scheduled Monument

ns:description.ns:full:
A cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other) and jet bead find of Bronze Age date. There is also a possible enclosure (an area of land enclosed by a boundary ditch, bank, wall, palisade or other similar barrier) of unknown date.

A number of small cairns discovered at Hurlbarrow during draining in 1964. A large quoit-shaped jet bead was found in one of them by Mr W Watson, the farmer. See the CBA Newsbulletin no. 4 january 1969 p. 10 (S1043). Also see article 'Prehistoric Habitation Sites in West Cumbria' by J. Cherry (S1868 p. 11-12). The site is visible on aerial photographs from the Cumbria County Council SMR as traces of an enclosure (S917). For details of archaeological investigation at this site see the NMR excavation index 628291 (S1347).

ns:appellation.ns:name: Kinmont Beck North West Cairnfield, Buckbarrow Bridge West Cairnfield

ns:description.ns:full:
Cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other) consisting of clearance cairns (irregularly constructed, generally unstructured, mounds of stones. Often, but not necessarily, circular. Normally a by product of field clearance for agricultural purposes) a funerary cairn (a stony mound containing or concealing deliberately deposited human remains) and associated field system (a group or complex of fields which appear to form a coherent whole) of Bronze Age date. Scheduled Ancient Monument no. 32834.

Several large irregular groups of cairns on Corney Fell. Seventy were examined and surveyed 1972. They were roughly circular and from 3-9 m in diam. The greatest concentration was on flat, dry ground. Two cairns were excavated. One was 4.3 m diam, the other 8 m diam. There were no finds but the second cairn had a roughly central patch of ash flecked with charcoal which may have been the remains of a burial. See article 'Cairns on Corney Fell' by J. Ward in the 1977 volume of C&WAAS for a summary of works conducted at this site (S1875 p. 1-5). For details of the 1972 excavation see the NMR excavation index 645903 (S1347). See the Inventory of ancient monuments in Cumberland in the 1923 volume of C&WAAS (S1905 p. 268). The AM County Index has this site divided into three parts, 015395-015397. This is the old scheduling areas (S904). Also see article in the CBA Archaeology Newsbulletin No. 3 January 1973 p. 2-3 (S1043). The site is included in T. Clare's MA thesis as site no. 396 (S1939) and George & Crawford's archaeological survey of Copeland (S1116 p. 51). According to OS inspection 31 May 1989, these are field clearance heaps, although there was no direct evidence of cultivation plots (S1361). The CLAU Survey of Corney Fell in 1984 surveyed 112 cairns and banks covering a larger area than previously thought. This has been rectified on the G.I.S. Other cairnfields were found in the area and these are SMR No.s 1404, 1453, 31007, 31008 and 31009. (S1915). The site forms part of an extensive area of cairnfields, field systems, hut circles and a farmstead. Kinmont Beck North West cairnfield (SAM 32834/01) is centred at approximately SD12709043 and includes over 100 clearance cairns varying between 2m-10m in diameter and up to 0.6m high. Within this cairnfield is a funerary cairn located at SD12749062. This cairn was subjected to limited excavation in 1972 and soil samples from beneath the mound were analysed and subsequently interpreted as indicating that the cairn had been used for burial. Also within this cairnfield are remains of a field system consisting of a lynchet running between two clearance cairns at the southern end of the cairnfield, lengths of stone banks interpreted as field divisions running down the hillslope, and alignments of clearance cairns considered to represent the line of old field boundaries in which sporadic patches of stone clearance were piled against hedges or fences. Buckbarrow Bridge West cairnfield is centred at approximately SD13119044 and lies either side of the minor road crossing Corney Fell. It includes upwards of 100 clearance cairns up to 0.6m high and varying between 3m in diameter to llm long by 8m wide. Within the cairnfield the are remains of a rectilinear field system represented by three lynchets, whilst a stone bank and an alignment of clearance cairns on the north side of the cairnfield and a stone bank on the south side of the cairnfield are also considered to have formed part of the field system. At the southern edge of the cairnfield, at SD13069032, there are remains of a hut circle about 4m in diameter (S905).

Monument Type: Monument

Monument Status: Scheduled Monument

ns:appellation.ns:name: Lath Rigg Prehistoric Cairnfield, Hut Circle and Field System on Thwaites Fell

ns:description.ns:full:
Clearance cairns (irregularly constructed, generally unstructured, mounds of stones. Often, but not necessarily, circular. Normally a by product of field clearance for agricultural purposes) and stone banks (linear or curvilinear constructions of stone) of Bronze Age date. Scheduled Ancient Monument no. 35014.

A great many small mounds and heaps of stone. Some have been dug in 1927. See article 'Explorations on Thwaites Fell' in the 1929 volume of C&WAAS (S2223 p. 250). The site is included in T. Clare's MA thesis as site no. 440 (S1939). A large area of clearance cairns, mostly ill-defined and in poor condition. There are sections of stone banks visible, but they too are ill-defined with a few small stones protruding (S1916). The scheduled monument includes Lath Rigg prehistoric cairnfield, hut circle and associated field system. It is located on gently-sloping fellside south and east of minor roads crossing Corney Fell and represents Bronze Age exploitation of the landscape. The cairnfield consists of over 100 round and oval-shaped clearance cairns up to 0.6m high; the round cairns measuring between 1.8m - 7.9m in diameter, the oval-shaped cairns measuring between 2.4m - 9.5m long by 1.5m - 6m wide. At SD1806 8906 there are the remains of a stone hut circle (HER 31013). Associated with the cairnfield and hut circle are faint traces of a field system formed by fragments of enclosures defined by stone banks or walls. There are two enclosures, both situated towards the northern end of the monument. The larger enclosure comprises a stone bank extending for approxiamtely 100m as two separate lengths of bank flanked by cairn-free areas on either side. The smaller enclosure is represented by two separate lengths of wall set at right angles to each other thus appearing to form the north and west sides with an entrance at the north west corner (S905). Bronze Age cairnfield and associated hut circle situated near to Lath Rigg on Thwaites Fell recorded by The National Trust Sites and Monuments Record (S2873). Part excavation work was undertaken in September 1927. Three were excavated. All revealed revetments of large stone enclosing cobble floor. The largest cairn, 28 feet by 16 feet, at the northeast of the fell near the road junction was shown to have a cist, though nothing was found within it (S2223, (S1361). Archaeological survey work has recorded the site as 112 sites; of these 100 are clearance cairns. Other features identified are a hollow, wall, earthwork banks, stone banks, a mound, a round cairn, a stone alignment, a rectangular cairn, a hut circle and an unassigned site (S??? - LUAU 1992, Thwaites Fell). Recording work by The National Trust also records a hut circle at SD 181 189, approximately 7 metres in internal diameter, composed of small stones. The stones, which are quite small, have traces of a bank or wall along their outer edge. The central area is not smooth, several stones project above the turf - this is clearly visible on aerial photograph OS 72/106 617 quoted by T Clare (S1939). The external diameter is 10.5 metres, internal diameter 8 metres, with approximately 10 stones set in the circle, average 0.4 - 0.6 metres across, with numerous smaller stones average 0.2 - 0.4 metres across, also set in the circle and scattered at random in the centre (S2884). Three of the cairns within the cairnfield was included in the LDNPA Volunteers Level 1 Woodland Survey conducted in 2013. Site TF10 was recorded as clearance cairn 3m diameter. Site TF11 was recorded as a possible burial cairn 5m diameter and 0.3m high. Site TF12 was recorded as a possible prehistoric cairn 4m diameter and 0.25m high.See photo#1 for Site TF11 and photo#2 for Site TF12 (S5269).

Monument Type: Monument

Monument Status: Scheduled Monument
